captions.text: Kal Penn: Hey, guys.
It's Kal Penn.

We got off Air Force One,
and now we're in a rickshaw
here in Delhi.

A lot of you might
be wondering,

why President Obama is in
India in the first place,

and what's that's
all about.
So let's dig into it.

This trip is a trip of firsts
-- not President Obama's
first trip to India.

He actually did
that back in 2010.

But with this visit
President Obama becomes

the first sitting U.S.
president to visit

India twice during
his time in office.
Why the second visit?

Well last September
Prime Minister Modi met

with President Obama
in Washington D.C.

on one of his earliest
trips in office.

They hit it off, and
following that trip,

he took the unprecedented
step of inviting

the President to be the
chief guest at India's
Republic Day celebrations.

So here's another first:
this visit will mark

the first time a U.S.
President will have

the honor of attending
Republic Day, which

commemorates the adoption
of India's constitution.
(music playing)

Kal Penn: But this is
much more than just
a symbolic visit.

This is actually an
opportunity for the world's

largest democracy, India, and
the world's oldest democracy,

America, to engage further
on some major issue
affecting both nations.

And who doesn't
love democracy?

Well I can think of some
people who don't like

democracy, but we're
not talking about
those people today.

So during the visit --
get ready for this --

we've seen a serious of
bilateral meetings and high

level dialogues advancing
U.S.-India economic ties,

and civil nuclear
understanding,

and the pursuit of increased
cooperation around

developing clean energy,
new defense initiatives,

security concerns, and
counter terrorism strategies,

the effort to combat
climate change,

the responsibility of
upholding fundamental

freedoms for all individuals,
regardless of gender,

orientation, or faith,
as well as the pursuit

of cleaner air, and
enhanced public pulse.
That's a lot, right?

The President: Well, we
can't tell you everything
that we talked about.

Yet there was still time to
honor the legacy of political

action through non-violent
means that binds both our

nations by paying respect
to Gandhi at a memorial.

While here the President also
released a video message back

home announcing new measures
the Department of Interior

is taking to preserve the
Artic Natural Wild Life Refuge

and calling on
Congress to designate

it a wilderness area,
which would keep it free
from roads and structures.

The President: So we can
make sure that this amazing

wonder is preserved for
future generations.

Kal Penn: Okay, so all
in all, really busy

weekend for President
Obama here in India.

Tune into this week's episode
of the West Wing Week airing

Friday to hear more about
the President's trip.

And now it's off
to Saudi Arabia.
(speaks Hindi)
(music playing)

title: On Board with Kal Penn: Travels with President Obama in India

comments.author: Oliwier EB

comments.text:
So this question has come up a few times and I'm going to share what I 
know. Is the U.S. the worlds oldest democracy? If you are talking about 
American Democracy in terms of the idea or the system then no, the concept 
of democracy has been talked about for a very long time and the idea has 
been experimented with the creations of parliaments in both the U.K., 
Ireland, and the Iroquoi Confederacy. However if we are talking in terms of 
states, or countries, then yes. To explain you have to understand that the 
definition of state and the concept of the state were first developed at 
the Treaty of Westphalia in 1648, this immediately disqualifies Greece and 
Rome which, on top of not really being democratic to begin with, were not 
states. This also disqualifies the Iroquoi Confederacy which was a 
collection of tribes working together, very democratic system, not a state. 
So what about the U.K. it had a parliament prior to the American Revolution 
didn't it? It did have a parliament before the establishment of the U.S. 
but to call it a democracy would be a mistake. Forget the fact that those 
in the House of Commons were related to those in the House of Lords,who 
themselves were selected by the monarch, we have to look at where the real 
power sat, and until the Victorian and Edward eras in the late 19th and 
early 20th centuries, the power mostly stayed with the crown and the lords. 
So to finish off the U.S. is not the oldest concept of democracy nor the 
oldest experiment, but it is the first state to meet the requirements of 
modern democracy and therefore the first and oldest democratic state.  ﻿

comments.text: Wait what? The US isn't the oldest democracy? Come on!!!﻿
comments.author: Elin Schiffer

comments.text:
+Daniel du Plooy "Say US is the oldest democracy" Some idiot online 
screamed propaganda for being wrong.
comments.author: nancy drew

comments.text: Who cares, should be a democracy, that's all it matters
comments.author: Akshat Punia

comments.text:
+Daniel du Plooy  
It is certainly one of the first democratic states, I suppose the U.K. had 
the right things in place to be considered a constitutional monarchy back 
in 1215, however arguably it seems to me it wasn't till the the reign of 
Queen Victoria and Edward VII that the British Monarch began to settle into 
its figure head role and stopped meddling in British politics with the 
Nobles. So I guess you could argue the U.S. to be the longest continually 
living democracy, though I am curious to hear what you say is the oldest 
longest living democracy and why. As for the Vikings and the iroquois 
confederacy, well the Vikings no longer exist and their settlement existed 
before the Treaty of Westphalia so it would not be able to call itself the 
longest continually living democratic state and the Iroquois confederacy no 
longer exists and I don't think it was a state to begin with, though I 
could be mistaken.
comments.author: Trevor Allen

comments.text:
+Joseph Anton Actually the first black man to vote in the U.S. was Thomas 
Mundy Peterson in March 31, 1870. They were not seen as equals, at least in 
the South, till the 60's. Before the Civil War they were seen as property 
not people in the U.S. and other countries where they were slaves. 
Fundamentally the U.S. has been a democracy since the ratification of the 
Constitution.
comments.author: Trevor Allen

comments.text:
+globalcitizenn No, the US is definately not the oldest democracy, that's

http://www.theguardian.com/notesandqueries/query/0,,-80426,00.html

comments.text:

comments.text:
America the worlds oldest democracy? No.
A quick Google search says "Democracy can be traced back from the present 
day to classical India or Athens in the 6th century B.C.E"
That makes India the worlds largest AND one of the world's oldest.﻿
comments.author: Mathew Hadder

comments.text: I was expecting such a comment to be posted ! Congrats you are the guy !
comments.author: Epicjack

comments.text:
+Rishabh Kumar the english didnt let the indian population have a 
democracy. the governors were appointed by the english rather then the 
citizens. plus gandhi did lead peaceful revolution by refusing to work and 
other acts of protest. and i know the english didnt have the economic 
ability to control such a piece of land
comments.author: Patrick O'Brian

comments.text:
Wrong again. Gandhi never lead any "revolution". The Brits didn't leave 
because Gandhi chased them away. Rather because WWII had them on their 
knees and they didn't have enough resources to manage large colonies. So 
they just left. A larger Independence Movement in India spans over a 
hundred years in India beginning right after 1857. With a major 
contribution by a Scotsman, Alan Octavian Hume. Indian civilization had 
variously had democratic governance in parts over the course of history. In 
fact right after human settlement in this land there is evidence of 
democracy. Pre-dating even the Greeks. When the Egyptians were building the 
pyramids we had structural proto democracies in a time period we refer to 
as the Vedic age. The concept of Election occurred to Indians before it 
even occurred tongue Greeks. Do read up on Vedic democracy.
comments.author: Rishabh Kumar

comments.text:
+Rishabh Kumar what time period do you think i'm talking about. the Indian 
population didn't have a democratic voting system at the time. it wasn't 
until Gandhi lead a peaceful  revolution for freedom from the British 
becoming independent and creating a Indian democracy
comments.author: Patrick O'Brian

comments.text:
+Patrick O'Brian .... O'Brian you really need to get yourself tested mate. 
XD
comments.author: Rishabh Kumar

comments.text: +Rishabh Kumar good you agree
comments.author: Patrick O'Brian

comments.text:

comments.text:
+Rishabh Kumar they took there land then made middle India a vassal.

comments.author: Patrick O'Brian

comments.text:
+Patrick O'Brian Since when did corporations start annexations? They may 
exploit and grab land. But they don't "annex". Annexation infers that the 
seceded territory merges into another territory. What did parts of India 
get "annexed" into? The Republic of Goldman-Sachs?
comments.author: Rishabh Kumar

comments.text: +Rishabh Kumar so yeah annexation by a corporation
comments.author: Patrick O'Brian

comments.text:
+Sujit Phatak Wow so you have resorted yourself to attacking me rather than 
doing any actual research. Have you even studied political science? At 
least I knew the status of slaves and when Blacks got the right to vote. 
Thanks for sharing your ignorance and destroying a civil debate. Please get 
an education and grow up.
comments.author: Trevor Allen

comments.text:
+Trevor Allen Are some of those Political Scientists also on board with the 
whole WMD Iraq thingy? Stop giving generic arguments with a whole group 
called Political Scientists as your evidence. Did you interview that whole 
global group? Get a grip man. Passing a bill is of no use if the society 
doesn't obey them and then wants to war against the use of law enforcement. 
I give you that on paper America might as well be the oldest democracy but 
in reality it isn't by any stretch of logic. I rest my case. I have a limit 
on how long to debate with a person with a dog cartoon as his profile 
picture on youtube and who watches insane amounts of gaming videos or 
things of that nature. Be well.
comments.author: Sujit Phatak

comments.text:
+Sujit Phatak The 15th Amendment to the Constitution granted African 
American men the right to vote by declaring that the "right of citizens of 
the United States to vote shall not be denied or abridged by the United 
States or by any state on account of race, color, or previous condition of 
servitude". It was illegal in ANY state at that point to deny a black man 
the right to vote. I'm just telling you what a political scientist 
professor told me on the subject. The whole problem had more to do with 
society than the Federal system. They were not considered citizens they 
were barely considered human.

Political scientists, who ultimately get the final call on this, call the 
U.S. a democratic state on the date of its founding because the system was 
democratic, flawed but democratic. There were free and fair elections and 
no polarization of power within the gov't, and a certain amount of freedom 
for citizens, which black slaves were not considered as.
comments.author: Trevor Allen

comments.text:
+Trevor Allen That would make New Jersey the oldest democracy but not the 
US. The essential condition for a Democratic State is when all of the 
citizens of that State get the voting rights. Just like a bunch of slave 
owners talking about freedom from the British are not talking about how 
humanity is inherently free but rather they are interested in a convenient 
selective freedom.
comments.author: Sujit Phatak

comments.text:
+Patrick O'Brian And there's no need for you to romanticize Great Britain 
as Britannia. "Britannia" had been "annexed" long before that by invading 
Saxons and French that murdered the native Celts by thousands.
comments.author: Rishabh Kumar

comments.text:
+Patrick O'Brian​​​ It wasn't "annexed" my friend. Annexation takes place 
when an army invades and conquers another country. The British East India 
Company (a corporation) came and made sly trade propositions, pitted Indian 
monarchs against each other, bullied them into submission with corporate 
might and guns (the powder for which they got from China) and when in 1857 
a large scale independence revolt started the British crushed it with a 
whole lot of bloodletting and then Queen Victoria issued the decree that 
all of India was "annexed" after that, even though not all parts of India 
were controlled by the British and they were not natives to be "annexing" 
any part of India. They were from a different part of the world. Meanwhile 
the Irish and the Scottish sympathized and some even actively sided with 
Indians during the British Raj's forceful rule in the coming years. Please 
brush up your history.
comments.author: Rishabh Kumar

comments.text:
During Obama's first visit in 2010 Sitaram Yechury a Member of Indian 
Parliament, actually took Obama's case when Obama said that USA is the 
world's oldest democracy at the State Dinner.
comments.author: Rishabh Kumar

comments.text:
+Sujit Phatak Thomas Mundy Peterson was the first black man to vote on 
March 31, 1870 in after the passage of the 15th Amendment following the 
American Civil War. It was in the Civil Rights movement they got finally 
recognized as equals. Anyway while a political scientist would agree it was 
flawed they would still call America a democratic state founded on 
democratic principles and behaved mostly as a democratic state, and 
therefore still the first democratic state.
comments.author: Trevor Allen

comments.text:
Also, blacks didnt have the voting rights till the 80s, that makes America 
not the oldest or even a continuing democracy.
comments.author: Sujit Phatak

comments.text:
+kvmanchow Actually it would be standards set in the time of the 
enlightenment and the Westphalia system established in 1648. Iceland can't 
be the first cause it wasn't a state till 1904, and Switzerland's Ancien 
Régime, might not have been so democratic. Especially when Napoleons 
puppets took over. It seems Switzerland is a democratic state in 1798 when 
it became a Federal Republic.
comments.author: Trevor Allen

comments.text:
+valcked Very well, lets agree to disagree. I am currently studying the 
subjects of history and politics here in the U.S. I'll admit I am no expert 
on the field, though I like to think I'm more knowledgeable then most, but

I wish you a good day and may both our countries strive to maintain and 
better themselves.
comments.author: Trevor Allen

comments.text:
I think we can keep at this for days, so I wont.
But it is great that it interests you, and obviously you dug into the 
subject. Hat off just for having the interest to do so, most people these 
days have the attention span of a flee.
So good sir, I wish you a great day and thank you for the great interaction 
on the subject!  :-)
Greetings from the small Belgium!
comments.author: valcked

comments.text:
+valcked Which ones? The two best contenders I can think of are the U.K. 
and the U.S., all the others had times where they had democratic 
institutions but either fell to more tyrannical internal forces or were 
conquered. I still don't know if the U.K. can be called a real 
constitutional democracy till 1782 when the House of commons made the 
government of Lord North resigned because the Commons did not support his 
policies. Showing that the elected officials held the real power for once. 
Also for a state to be a democracy the people must have the power, a state 
is not a democracy because it has elections but because either the people 
or representatives chosen by the people have the true power.
comments.author: Trevor Allen

comments.text:
Well, I'll keep it limited to this:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_democracy

Scholars in history will be able to fill this in better then I can. In each 
case, and not to put to fine a point on it, it is not the USA.

There are many countries that where and still are democratic (i.e. 
government elected by the people with a representative government). It is 
not because there is a King/Queen that it is not a democracy.
comments.author: valcked

comments.text:
It is certainly one of the first democratic states, I suppose the U.K. had 
the right things in place to be considered a constitutional monarchy back 
in 1215, however arguably it seems to me it wasn't till the the reign of 
Queen Victoria and Edward VII that the British Monarch began to settle into 
its figure head role and stopped meddling in British politics with the 
Nobles. So I guess you could argue the U.S. to be the longest continually 
living democracy, though I am curious to hear what you say is the oldest 
longest living democracy and why.
